authors: Wu, Q;  Tambunlertchai, K;  Pornchaiwiseskul, P
title: Examining the Impact and Influencing Channels of Carbon Emission Trading Pilot Markets in China
usedData:
China Statistical Yearbook, China Energy Statistical
Yearbook and the Carbon Emission Accounts & Datasets (CEADs)- CO2 emission data were obtained from CEADs (alternate measures also exist, such as the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) approach
notes: Mean annual counterfactual emissions (in 10000 tons of CO2) during the treatment period (2014-2016)
label: Wu et al. (2021)
Notes.RoB.selection: The treatment group includes Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, Hubei, Chongqing, Guangdong and Fujian involved in pilots, other provinces formed the control group
Notes.RoB.confounders: Controls time fixed effects and province fixed effects. Includes control variables : GDP per capita, pollution control investment, technology introduction, industrial structure,  energy structure and factor endowment

authors: Xu, WZ
title: The Impact and Influencing Path of the Pilot Carbon Emission Trading market--Evidence From China
usedData: Yearbook of China, yearbook of each province, China energy statistical yearbook from 2009 to 2020, National Bureau of Statistics, Marketization Index of China’s Provinces, 2018
notes: Mean annual emissions (in ln CO2) of the full sample over the full observation period
label: Xu (2021)
Notes.RoB.selection: The treatment group includes eight carbon emission trade pilot provinces: Beijing, Guangdong,Tianjin, Shanghai, Hubei, and Chongqing, which begin to implement the policy in 2013 and 2014; and Fujian and Sichuan which started from 2016 to 2017. Tibet is exempt from this research due to missing data, so the control group includes the other 22 provinces of mainland China except for the experimental group and Tibet.
Notes.RoB.confounders: Controls time fixed effects and province fixed effects. Includes control variables : GDP, resident population, energy structure, industrial structure, energy endowment

authors: Yajima, N.;  Arimura, T.H.;  Sadayuki, T.
title: Energy consumption in transition: Evidence from facility-level data
usedData: CSEC (conducted by the Agency for Natural Resources and Energy in Japan)
notes: NA
label: Yajima et al. (2021)
Notes.RoB.selection: The dataset used in the study coveres nine energy intensive industries and only includes facilities as of a defined threshold of employees (the threshold varies by industry).
Notes.RoB.confounders: The study controles for cooling- and heating-degree days as well as energy prices. Other time and facility differences are controlled for by fixed effects, which should compensate for not including other economic variables.

authors: Yan, JC
title: The impact of climate policy on fossil fuel consumption: Evidence from the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI)
usedData: Detailed monthly state-level electric power data pro- vided by the EIA (U.S. Energy Information Administration)
notes: Impact on RGGI states. The study estimates the impact of RGGI on the level of coal and natural gas consumption, and uses these estimates to roughly calculate the amount of carbon dioxide emissions reduced by the program (based on the average heat content of coal in the electric power sector from 2009 to 2018 and coal CO2 content of 205 lbs./MMBtu, and based on the average heat content of natural gas in the electric power sector from 2009 to 2018 and a CO2 gas content of 117 lbs./MMBtu)
label: Yan (2021)
Notes.RoB.selection: The treatment group consists of RGGI states (except for New Jersey which withdrew from RGGI during the study period). New Jersey is not included in any of the two groups.
Notes.RoB.confounders: Controls state fixed effects and month-year fixed effects. Includes control variables : other environmental policies such as the renewable portfolio standard (RPS) . It also includes a separate treatment effect for the potential leaker states Pennsylvania and Ohio, to avoid an overestimation of the reduction effect.

authors: Yang, BW; Liu, LP; Yin, YH
title: Will China's low-carbon policy balance emission reduction and economic development? Evidence from two provinces
usedData: national bureau of statistics, China statistical yearbook and China energy statistical yearbook
notes: The metric of the effect size as well as the mean are unclear, but they are of the same metric. The mean was calculated from Table three, averaging the counterfactual emissions after implementation.
label: Yang et al. (2021)
Notes.RoB.selection:
The study analyses the effect of the Hubei pilot ETS and uses the other non-pilot regions as a control group. It is not clear why only one of the pilot regions is analysed, though it is argued that "the economic growth, industrial structure and energy
structure of Hubei province are very representative" and it has the largest carbon market in China in terms of trading volume and other indicators. The selection of the control variables is enhanced by using a SCM.
Notes.RoB.confounders: The study uses a number of economic, demographic and energy variables to weight the donor provinces.

authors: Yang, XY; Jiang, P; Pan, Y
title: Does China's carbon emission trading policy have an employment double dividend and a Porter effect?
usedData: China Statistical Yearbook
notes: Mean emissions are taken from table 3 and represent mean emissions in treated areas during treatment period, but the metric is not known.
label: Yang et al. (2020)
Notes.RoB.selection: The study analyses Chinese regions with and without ETS policies.
Notes.RoB.confounders: The study controlls for various economic, demographic and regulation factors and uses object and time fixed effects.
Notes.RoB.other: The analysed data is discribed as: "this paper selects industrial enterprises above the designated scale from 2006 to 2016 in 30 Chinese provinces and cities". Thus the data cannot be expected to be complete or representative.

authors: Yang, ZF;  Yuan, YN;  Zhang, QZ
title: Carbon Emission Trading Scheme, Carbon Emissions Reduction and Spatial Spillover Effects: Quasi-Experimental Evidence From China
usedData: China UrbanStatistical Yearbook, China Energy Statistical Yearbook
notes: Mean annual emissions (log of carbon emissions) of the full sample (29 provinces) over the full observation period (2003-2019)
label: Yang et al. (2022)
Notes.RoB.selection: The sample included data from 29 provinces and municipalities from 2003 to 2019 ( ETS in Fujian Province was established in 2017, which is different from other pilot regions and the pilot operation period is relatively short, so Fujian Province is excluded from the sample in this paper). The treatment group is made up of the two pilot provinces and four municipalities directly under the central government that implemented the ETS, and the control group is made up of the non-pilot provinces and autonomous regions.
Notes.RoB.confounders: Controls time fixed effects and province fixed effects. Includes control variables : Industrialization level ; economic development leve; population density ; international direct investment ; service industry development level ; degree of openness to the world

Notes.RoB.selection: The sample included data from 29 provinces and municipalities from 2003 to 2019 ( ETS in Fujian Province was established in 2017, which is different from other pilot regions and the pilot operation period is relatively short, so Fujian Province is excluded from the sample in this paper). The treatment group is made up of the two pilot provinces and four municipalities directly under the central government that implemented the ETS, and the control group is made up of the non-pilot provinces and autonomous regions.
Notes.RoB.confounders: Controls time fixed effects and province fixed effects. Includes control variables : Industrialization level ; economic development leve; population density ; international direct investment ; service industry development level ; degree of openness to the world

authors: Yang, ZF;  Yuan, YN;  Zhang, QZ
title: Carbon Emission Trading Scheme, Carbon Emissions Reduction and Spatial Spillover Effects: Quasi-Experimental Evidence From China
usedData: China UrbanStatistical Yearbook, China Energy Statistical Yearbook
notes: SDID model under the local spatial distance weight Matrix within the 600 km range of the pilot regions - Mean annual emissions (log of carbon emissions) of the full sample (29 provinces) over the full observation period (2003-2019)
label: Yang et al. (2022)
Notes.RoB.selection: The sample included data from 29 provinces and municipalities from 2003 to 2019 ( ETS in Fujian Province was established in 2017, which is different from other pilot regions and the pilot operation period is relatively short, so Fujian Province is excluded from the sample in this paper). The treatment group is made up of the two pilot provinces and four municipalities directly under the central government that implemented the ETS, and the control group is made up of the non-pilot provinces and autonomous regions.
Notes.RoB.confounders: Controls time fixed effects and province fixed effects. Includes control variables : Industrialization level ; economic development leve; population density ; international direct investment ; service industry development level ; degree of openness to the world

authors: Yi, L; Bai, N; Yang, L; Li, ZP; Wang, F
title: Evaluation on the effectiveness of China's pilot carbon market policy
Notes.largerRoB: Estimation without control variables and fixed effects.
usedData: National Bureau of Statistics and Wind Database
notes: The provided uncertainty measures are presented by the authors as standard errors. However, we interprete them as t-statistic, as this is much more plausible (most of them are negative and the sizes fit a t-statistic well). The mean emissions are the mean across the five studied pilot regions, though each effect size only refers to a single treated region (Table 2, row 1, col 1).
label: Yi et al. (2020)
Notes.RoB.selection: The study uses the Chinese pilot ETS regions as treatment group and the remaining regions as control group. For each pilot region it selects a set of conrol regions according to the criterion of paralell trends before the policy implementation. For Chonqing no control set satisfies the paralell trend condition. Therefore it is excluded from the study.
Notes.RoB.confounders: The study controlls for a set of economic, demographic and energy variables and includes time and region fixed effects.
Notes.RoB.other: The study includes 48-108 observations and uses up to 29 regression coefficients incl. fixed effects (own calculation). This likely leeds to overfitting of the model. (R² is reported as 0.99 and 1.00 for some of the specifications.)

Notes.RoB.other: The study includes 48-108 observations and uses up to 29 regression coefficients incl. fixed effects (own calculation). This likely leeds to overfitting of the model. (R² is reported as 0.99 and 1.00 for some of the specifications.)

authors: Yi, L; Bai, N; Yang, L; Li, ZP; Wang, F
title: Evaluation on the effectiveness of China's pilot carbon market policy
Notes.largerRoB: The regression uses all non-pilot regions except for those that were previously detected to have the most similar trend to the treated region before the policy implementation. (robustness check)
usedData: National Bureau of Statistics and Wind Database
notes: The provided uncertainty measures are presented by the authors as standard errors. However, we interprete them as t-statistic, as this is much more plausible (most of them are negative and the sizes fit a t-statistic well). The mean emissions are the mean across the five studied pilot regions, though each effect size only refers to a single treated region (Table 2, row 1, col 1).
label: Yi et al. (2020)
Notes.RoB.selection: The study uses the Chinese pilot ETS regions as treatment group and the remaining regions as control group. For each pilot region it selects a set of conrol regions according to the criterion of paralell trends before the policy implementation. For Chonqing no control set satisfies the paralell trend condition. Therefore it is excluded from the study.
Notes.RoB.confounders: The study controlls for a set of economic, demographic and energy variables and includes time and region fixed effects.
Notes.RoB.other: The study includes 48-108 observations and uses up to 29 regression coefficients incl. fixed effects (own calculation). This likely leeds to overfitting of the model. (R² is reported as 0.99 and 1.00 for some of the specifications.)

authors: Zhang, HJ; Duan, MS; Deng, Z
title: Have China's pilot emissions trading schemes promoted carbon emission reductions?- the evidence from industrial sub-sectors at the provincial level
Notes.largerRoB: No fixed effects, no control varibales
usedData: Provincial statistical yearbook, China’s price Statistics yearbook, China Energy statistical yearbook, China Labour Statistical yearbook
notes: The mean emissions are the average annual emissions for the full sample over the full observation period (2005-2015) in millions tons, obtained from table 1 page 916. It corresponds to the  sum of emissions for Treatment group and Control group. While the paper claims to report t-statistics, the values rather appear to be standard errors (all positive, small values, t-statistics would not be in line with reported significance level) and are thus interpreted that way.
label: Zhang, Duan & Deng (2019)
Notes.RoB.selection: The study includes 37 subsectors in 26 provinces of China from 2005 to 2015. Industrial subsectors covered by pilots are in the treatment group, uncovered industrial subsectors in pilot and non pilot regions are in the control group
Notes.RoB.confounders: Includes individual and province-year fixed effects, and control variables (gross outputs, gross outputs per capita,, ratio of state-owned assets, ratio of fixed assets, profitability))

authors: Zhang, HJ; Duan, MS; Deng, Z
title: Have China's pilot emissions trading schemes promoted carbon emission reductions?- the evidence from industrial sub-sectors at the provincial level

authors: Zhang, HJ; Duan, MS; Deng, Z
title: Have China's pilot emissions trading schemes promoted carbon emission reductions?- the evidence from industrial sub-sectors at the provincial level
Notes.largerRoB: Match on pretreatment carbon emission and sectors, covariate balanacing is less good
usedData: Provincial statistical yearbook, China’s price Statistics yearbook, China Energy statistical yearbook, China Labour Statistical yearbook

It corresponds to the  sum of emissions for Treatment group and Control group

authors: Zhang, HJ; Duan, MS; Zhang, P
title: Analysis of the Impact of China's Emissions Trading Scheme on Reducing Carbon Emissions
usedData: IPPC Greenhouse gas inventory 2006 ; Guidelines for Provincial Greenhouse Gas inventories, National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), 2011.
notes: While the paper claims to report t-statistics, the values rather appear to be standard errors (all positive, small values, t-statistics would not be in line with reported significance level) and are thus interpreted that way. Mean emissions are the average annual emissions in thousand tons for the full sample  over the full observation period (2005-2015) obtained from table 1 page 3599. It corresponds to the  sum of emissions for Treatment group (9143,2) and Control group (6260,4)))
label: Zhang, Duan & Zhang (2019)
Notes.RoB.selection: The study includes 39 sectors of 24 provinces. Sectors covered by ETS in the pilots region are the treatment group ; sectors not covered by ETS in the pilots and non pilots regiond are the control goup. Due to the lack of data on energy consumption per detailed sector, Shanghai is not included in the pilot region, and Zhejiang, Jiangsu, Sichuan and Tibet are not included in the control group
Notes.RoB.confounders: Sector, individual-sector and province-year fixed effects included, but no other control variables

authors: Zhang, HR; Zhang, RX; Li, GM; Li, W; Choi, Y
title: Has China's Emission Trading System Achieved the Development of a Low-Carbon Economy in High-Emission Industrial Subsectors?
usedData: provincial statistical yearbook (2006–2018)
notes: Mean emissions are only provided in logarithmised form. The study also explains some propensity score matching methods, but does not apply them to construct a control group. The study also conducts some DDD estimations, which are not captured here, as the effect sizes are not easily interpretable.
label: Zhang, Zhang et al. (2020)
Notes.RoB.selection: The study studies subsectors from Chinese provinces. It includes observations from provinces which introduced the ETS and from those that did not. In the ETS provinces some of the subsectors are treated and others are not. So the controll group is made up of subsectors in the treated provinces that are not covered by the policy as well as all subsectors from untreated provinces. It is unclear whether the emissions in different sectors are well suited as a control group.
Notes.RoB.confounders: The study controlls for "GDP, gearing ratio, labor productivity, energy efficiency, R&D ratio, and R&D intensity" and uses time and object fixed effects.
Notes.RoB.other: The reported results are likely false reported. A number of results are highlighted and interpreted as significant, while the reported effect size and standard error do not allow for this interpretation.

authors: Zhang, W; Li, J; Li, GX; Guo, SC
title: Emission reduction effect and carbon market efficiency of carbon emissions trading policy in China
usedData:
China’s Statistical Yearbook, from 2008 to 2016; China’s Energy Statistical Yearbook, from 2008 to
2016; China’s Industrial Statistical Yearbook, from 2008 to 2016; and
the 2008e2016 statistical yearbooks of 30 provinces and cities
notes: Mean emissions are only reported logarithmised (in the online appendix).
label: Zhang, Li, Li & Gao (2020)
Notes.RoB.selection:
The study uses Chinese regions with pilot ETS as treatment group and the remaining Chinese regions as control group. They use data "from the industrial enterprises
above designated size". They do not seem to cover the whole sector.
Notes.RoB.confounders: The study uses population size, GDP, "technical level", "economic structure", and the number of heavy industry enterprises as control variables. It does not use fixed effects.

usedData: Energy consumption data between 2008 and 2016 from China Energy Statistical Yearbook (2009-2017) ; energy consumption in 2017 from Bulletin of the reduction rate of energy consumption per 10000 Yuan gross domestic product of provinces (regions, cities) in 2017 ; control variables from China Statistical Yearbook (2009-2018)
notes: 2015 estimation ; The mean emissions are the average annual emissions in 10000 ton for the full sample over the full observation period (2008-2017) obtained from table 2 page 4
label: Zhang & Zhang (2019)
Notes.RoB.selection: The study includes 30 provinces in China from 2008 to 2017, and exludes Hong Kong, Macao, Tibet.
Notes.RoB.confounders: Includes time and regional fixed effects, and control variables (population, GDP, ratio of the secondary industry, technical level and income level)

authors: Zhang, YF; Li, S; Luo, TY; Gao, J
title: The effect of emission trading policy on carbon emission reduction: Evidence from an integrated study of pilot regions in China
usedData: China Environmental Yearbook 2004-2016
notes: NA
label: Zhang, Li, Luo & Gao (2020)
Notes.RoB.selection: The study includes 11 treated and 102 untreated cities. There is no transparent criterion for the choice of the treated cities provided. It is thus likely to be a biased set of all cities.
Notes.RoB.confounders: The study controls for "population size, economic size, industrial structure, and foreign direct investment" and uses time and object fixed effects.

authors: Zhang, YJ; Peng, YL; Ma, CQ; Shen, B
title: Can environmental innovation facilitate carbon emissions reduction? Evidence from China
usedData: Recalculation of coal, oil and natural gas consumption following IPPC guidelines; unclear where to information about fuel consumption comes from
notes: Analysis on 30 (all?) Chinese provinces. Mean emissions irretrivable.
label: Zhang et al. (2017)
Notes.RoB.selection: three specified fuels oil, gas, coal are analysed for all Chinese provinces; different matching algorithms are applied to match treated provinces to untreated provinces
Notes.RoB.confounders: The study uses DiD combined with the following matching approach: With respect to their matching, the authors note: "According to the Notice on Carrying the Carbon Emission Trading Pilot issued by the NDRC in 2011, six indicators were selected as independent variables which were then used to calculate the propensity, including the level of economic development (GDP), industrial structure (SER), marketization (MA), energy consumption tructure (ECS), and the number of enterprises (ENT). Based on the panel data of 30 provinces before the implementation of CET (i.e., 2000–2011)". Table A2 confirms that the matching leaves a controlgroup with high similarities to the treatment group.

authors: Zhou, YS; Huang, L
title: How regional policies reduce carbon emissions in electricity markets: Fuel switching or emission leakage
usedData: EIA survey forms EIA-860, EIA-861, EIA-923
notes: The study also analyses how much of the emission reduction is explained by leakage. This is not covered here. So all estimates represent the gross reduction in the treated area. The mean price level was not reported in the paper, but was provided by the authors uppon request.
label: Zhou & Huang (2021)
Notes.RoB.selection: The study uses power utilities from RGGI states as treatment group and utilities from other states as controls, covering a total of 692 power utilities, of which 15.6% are in the treated area. The estimations are conducted separately for coal, gas and mixed power plants which can switch between the two. This means that each estimate is only representative of the specific plant type. It does not allow to aggregate over plant types.
Notes.RoB.confounders:
The study includes coal-gas price ratio, output capacity,
CHP capacity ratio, utility age, and electricitymarket deregulation status as control variables and includes time and firm fixed effects.
Notes.RoB.other: For price elasticity estimations the endogeneity problem is rather small, since the study uses firm level data, where the influence of a single firm on the carbon price is rather small.

authors: Zhou, YS; Huang, L
title: How regional policies reduce carbon emissions in electricity markets: Fuel switching or emission leakage
usedData: EIA survey forms EIA-860, EIA-861, EIA-923
notes: The study also analyses how much of the emission reduction is explained by leakage. This is not covered here. So all estimates represent the gross reduction in the treated area. The mean price level was not reported in the paper, but was provided by the authors uppon request.
label: Zhou & Huang (2021)
Notes.RoB.selection: The study uses power utilities from RGGI states as treatment group and utilities from other states as controls, covering a total of 692 power utilities, of which 15.6% are in the treated area. The estimations are conducted separately for coal, gas and mixed power plants which can switch between the two. This means that each estimate is only representative of the specific plant type. It does not allow to aggregate over plant types.
Notes.RoB.confounders:
The study includes coal-gas price ratio, output capacity,
CHP capacity ratio, utility age, and electricitymarket deregulation status as control variables and includes time and firm fixed effects.
Notes.RoB.other: For price elasticity estimations the endogeneity problem is rather small, since the study uses firm level data, where the influence of a single firm on the carbon price is rather small.

authors: Dong, ZQ; Wang, H; Wang, SX; Wang, LH
title: The validity of carbon emission trading policies: Evidence from a quasi-natural experiment in China
usedData:
From the paper: "The data of carbon emission is
calculated according to the consumption and carbon emission
coefficient of different energy (Shen et al., 2012). The standard
coal coefficient of energy used in calculation is from
Chinese Energy Statistics Yearbook 2018. The carbon emission
coefficient is from IPCC 2006 Guidelines for National
Greenhouse Gas Inventories (Shi and Hu, 2017)."
notes: Only significance level reported, no other uncertainty measures
label: Dong et al. (2020)
Notes.RoB.selection: All Chinese provinces with ETS as treated and all Chinese provinces w/o ETS as untreated in a Diff-in-Diff framework
Notes.RoB.confounders: Reasonable set of control variables as described in table 1

authors: Wang, XX;  Huang, JL;  Liu, HD
title: Can China's carbon trading policy help achieve Carbon Neutrality?-A study of policy effects from the Five-sphere Integrated Plan perspective
usedData: Energy usage data and data on carbon sinks was transformed with IPCC 2006 values to come up with transformed net carbon emissions; data source of energy usage unclear
notes: NA
label: Wang et al. (2022)
Notes.RoB.selection: The treatment group consists of all Chinese provinces which introduced an ETS pilot. All other Chinese regions are used as a control group.
Notes.RoB.confounders: The study controls for a set of economic and policy variables.
